The AMIE algorithm [8,9] is a method to mine closed Horn rules on large KBs.

Once AMIE has found the set of possible values for x with Algorithm 2, it determines, for each value of x, the possible values of y -again by Algorithm 2. This is necessary because we cannot keep in memory all values of y encountered when we computed the values of x, because this would lead to a quadratic memory consumption.

Therefore, AMIE [8] has proposed the Partial Completeness Assumption (PCA): If we have r(s, o) in the KB K, and if fun(r) ≥ fun(r -), then we assume that all r(s, o') ∈ K do not hold in the real world.

By default, AMIE uses the PCA confidence to assess the quality of a rule, because it has been shown to rank rules closer to the quality of their predictions than classical metrics such as the CWA confidence [8].
